text: hey friend i come asking question about workplace anxiety i m 9 and work retail i realize that this is a job with low stake and that whatever fear i have about making mistake are rather silly given the nature of the job however i ve worked myself up because i worked an event this evening and in my eye it wa just a series of unfortunate event first i show up early but still later than my coworker who i wa working with for the event he wa talking to our bos second i wa underdressed he looked so sharp granted i am 9 and he is almost a full decade older than me with the life experience to really comprehend dress code it wa rather unspecified and unclear so i m trying not to beat myself up too much about it i ran home super quickly and grabbed some nicer shoe and a jacket but it still wasn t great third my bos gave u her number to text or to call if we needed any help i texted her first and then she asked if i would call her because she wa on the road make sense but i feel i made a mistake texting her in the first place fourth fifth sixth and so on i worry that throughout the entire evening i wad screwing up and ended up losing the store a ton of money i m so upset about everything that happened and being liked by my bos that i wa cry and now i can t sleep please oh please i beg of y all how do i get over this it s making my day really difficult and i don t want this to follow me into the future when if i have a job much more demanding and serious if i mess up it s eating me up and i can t take it thanks
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text exhibits several indicators that suggest moderate depression:

*   **Anxiety and Worry:** The individual expresses significant anxiety specifically centered around workplace performance and perceived mistakes. The constant worrying and overthinking ("fourth fifth sixth and so on i worry that throughout the entire evening i wad screwing up") are characteristic of anxiety, a common co-occurring symptom of depression.
*   **Negative Self-Perception:** There is evidence of negative self-perception and self-criticism. The individual focuses on perceived failures and shortcomings ("I was underdressed," "I feel I made a mistake texting her in the first place," "losing the store a ton of money").
*   **Emotional Distress and Dysregulation:** The text conveys strong emotional distress ("I was crying," "I can't sleep"). This indicates difficulty regulating emotions, a hallmark of depression.
*   **Impact on Daily Functioning:** The anxiety and distress are impacting the individual's daily life ("It's making my day really difficult") and causing sleep disturbances.
*   **Fear of the Future:** The individual expresses fear of future work and the consequences of potential mistakes. This suggests a generalized anxiety and a pessimistic outlook, both associated with depression.
*   **Seeking Reassurance:** The individual is seeking reassurance and guidance from others ("please oh please i beg of y all how do i get over this"). This implies a sense of helplessness and a need for external validation, which can be indicative of low self-esteem and depression.

While the individual acknowledges that the job is low-stakes, their emotional reaction is disproportionate to the situation, suggesting an underlying vulnerability to anxiety and depressive symptoms. The combination of these factors warrants a rating of moderate depression.

text: hey guy today i opened up to my boyfriend for the first time in a while about all the mental turmoil i ve been going through a part of me want to cut it off i love him dearly but i just feel like i ll be a burden to him for the rest of my life if i stay is it selfish to leave or selfish to stay if i knew he d be fine if i knew he d make it and be happy with someone else one day i would leave i would spend all the money i have chasing fleeting happiness until i m ready to go i wish i could erase the memory from his head so he can just know peace
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text exhibits several indicators of severe depression:

*   **Mental Turmoil:** The individual explicitly states they are experiencing significant mental distress.
*   **Feelings of Burden:** The belief that they will be a burden on their boyfriend for life is a classic symptom of depression, often stemming from feelings of worthlessness and low self-esteem.
*   **Suicidal Ideation (Passive):** The desire to "cut it off" and the contemplation of leaving, coupled with wishing to "erase the memory" suggests passive suicidal thoughts. While not explicitly stating a desire to die, the wish to disappear and remove themselves from the situation is concerning.
*   **Hopelessness:** The phrase "if I knew he'd be fine... I would leave" indicates a lack of hope that the relationship can improve and a belief that they are inherently detrimental to their boyfriend's well-being.
*   **Desire for Fleeting Happiness:** The urge to chase "fleeting happiness until I'm ready to go" may indicate a sense of meaninglessness and a desperate attempt to find temporary relief from the underlying pain. The phrase "ready to go" could be interpreted as passive thoughts of ending their life.
*   **Guilt and Self-Blame:** The questions about whether it's selfish to leave or stay highlight significant guilt and self-blame.

These factors combined point towards a severe level of depression requiring immediate attention.

text: i stopped my dad from killing himself yesterday and idk what i should do i don t know how to help him i offered to help him talk to a therapist but he said no i m afraid to lose him when i pulled the gun out of his hand he looked so scared and overwhelmed he even said thank you for now i took the gun from the house i hope to god it wa just a one off and he won t try again but i don t know how to help i know i can call 9 and they will put him in a hospital for his own safety i don t know i m scared of doing that he doesn t like hospital any help would be appreciated i m completely lost
explanation:
**Explanation:**

This text excerpt indicates a high level of distress and concern, stemming from a very serious event – the individual's father attempting suicide. Here's a breakdown of why it's rated as severe:

*   **Suicidal Ideation/Attempt:** The father's attempted suicide is the most significant indicator. This demonstrates a profound level of despair and hopelessness.
*   **Fear and Anxiety:** The individual expresses intense fear of losing their father, highlighting their emotional investment and the potential for grief.
*   **Helplessness and Confusion:** The statement "I don't know what I should do," "I don't know how to help him," and "I'm completely lost" reveals a strong sense of powerlessness and being overwhelmed by the situation. This is a common symptom of depression, particularly when faced with a crisis.
*   **Trauma:** Witnessing a suicide attempt is a traumatic experience, and the individual's recounting of the event ("when I pulled the gun out of his hand he looked so scared and overwhelmed") suggests they are processing this trauma.
*   **Concern about Involuntary Hospitalization:** The individual's hesitancy to call for professional help due to their father's aversion to hospitals indicates a complex dilemma and further adds to their stress.
*   **Hopelessness:** The statement "I hope to god it was just a one off and he won't try again but I don't know how to help" reveals a sense of uncertainty and underlying fear that the situation might not improve.

Given the severity of the situation, the individual's emotional distress, and their expressed feelings of helplessness, a rating of 3 (Severe Depression) is warranted. They require immediate support and guidance to navigate this crisis and manage their own emotional well-being.

text: i feel lonely today

**Explanation:**

text: rachelcmrn i don t like goodnights
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The statement "I don't like goodnights" is a subtle but potentially significant indicator of depression. Here's why:

*   **Ahedonia/Loss of Interest:** Disliking "goodnights" can suggest a lack of enjoyment or contentment in what is usually a peaceful and comforting part of the day. This aligns with *ahedonia*, a core symptom of depression where individuals lose interest or pleasure in things they used to enjoy.

*   **Negative Association:** The statement implies a negative association with the end of the day. This could be due to increased rumination, anxiety, or feelings of dread that worsen at night, which are common experiences for people with depression.

*   **Low Mood:** It can subtly indicate a general low mood or dissatisfaction with life, where even simple comforts like the end of the day are unappealing.

Because this is a single, brief statement, it's impossible to definitively diagnose depression. However, the statement raises enough concerns to warrant further investigation and a rating of 2, indicating the presence of moderate depression. A more comprehensive assessment, including other symptoms and the individual's history, would be necessary for an accurate diagnosis.

text: i m thinking about killing myself since i m almost did it time and had multiple breakdown the last year i m now and nothing changed but i want to get better how do i tell my parent i really need some advice please

*   **Desire for Help:** While the individual expresses a desire to get better and seeks advice, this does not negate the severity of the suicidal ideation and other factors. It indicates a potential window of opportunity for intervention.

text: i have been trying to drop in on a ramp every time i do it in the last second i lean back and fall i can simulate it in my head but my fear or anxiety prevents me i literally went skydiving last week but i can not get myself to do a simple trick i ve fallen plenty of time so what s the worst thing that can happen it s weird how fear is relative i go skydiving one week and the next week i get nervous while driving or when talking to a girl one ha more fatal consequence while the other one just make me nervous i want to conquer all fear but trying new thing is always stressful
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text suggests mild depression based on the following observations:

*   **Anxiety and Fear:** There is clear mention of anxiety and fear preventing them from achieving their goal. While not directly indicative of depression, persistent anxiety can be a contributing factor or comorbidity.
*   **Negative Self-Perception/Frustration:** The individual expresses confusion and frustration about their fear response ("it's weird how fear is relative"). This can point to a negative self-perception or a feeling of being inadequate.
*   **Stress:** The individual states that trying new things is always stressful. Elevated stress levels can be a symptom of depression or increase one's susceptibility to depression.

It's important to note that this is a mild rating because there's no mention of core depressive symptoms like persistent sadness, hopelessness, sleep disturbances, or changes in appetite. The primary focus is on fear and frustration, which are more closely associated with anxiety but can also overlap with depressive experiences.

text: i got broken up with overnight a year relationship because she thought for a week that she s falling out of love i am absolutely devastated i can t carry on with my life and truly am considering ending it all i think i am gon na do it because she wa the only one for me what is the best way not to hurt your family thanks

**Explanation:**

This text exhibits several critical indicators of severe depression and suicidal ideation:

*   **Devastation and Inability to Function:** The individual expresses being "absolutely devastated" and unable to "carry on with my life." This suggests a significant impairment in their ability to engage in daily activities and experience pleasure.

*   **Suicidal Ideation:** The explicit statement "truly am considering ending it all" is a direct expression of suicidal ideation, which is a serious warning sign.

*   **Hopelessness and Loss of Meaning:** The belief that the ex-partner "was the only one" indicates a profound sense of hopelessness and a lack of belief that they can find happiness or fulfillment in the future. This contributes to the severity of the depression.

*   **Planning/Preparation (Implied):** Asking "what is the best way not to hurt your family" may suggest that the individual is in the process of planning or thinking about the logistics of suicide.

Given the presence of suicidal ideation, hopelessness, and significant functional impairment, this text indicates a high level of distress and warrants immediate professional intervention.

text: i like not caring about anything i m at work all day just going through the motion the long hour and annoying customer don t phase me because i m not even all there mentally emotionally failing uni doesn t phase me because eh i have to be numb because if not i ll just constantly feel unbearable emotional and physical pain i have to swallow every bit of emotion so i don t completely fall apart
explanation:
**Explanation:**

This text demonstrates several indicators of severe depression:

*   **Anhedonia and Apathy:** The individual explicitly states "I like not caring about anything" and describes "going through the motions" at work. This signifies a loss of interest and pleasure in activities, a core symptom of depression.
*   **Emotional Numbness:** The individual actively suppresses emotions ("I have to be numb," "swallow every bit of emotion") as a coping mechanism to avoid "unbearable emotional and physical pain." This points to a significant level of distress and a deliberate attempt to detach from feelings, which is often seen in severe depression.
*   **Sense of Failure and Worthlessness:** The phrase "emotionally failing uni doesn’t phase me because eh" shows they are failing academically, which would often cause distress, but they indicate that they are again, emotionless about it.
*   **Avoidance of Pain:** The individual fears the consequences of feeling emotions ("if not I'll just constantly feel unbearable emotional and physical pain"), indicating a deep-seated sense of suffering and a strong desire to avoid it, often linked with suicidal ideation or self-harm in severe cases.
*   **Impairment of Functioning:** While not explicitly stated, the need to be constantly numb to cope with work and university implies a significant impairment in daily functioning. They aren’t able to healthily process their emotions, thus affecting their quality of life.
*   **Potential for Crisis:** The statement "so I don't completely fall apart" suggests a fragile emotional state and a potential for a complete breakdown or crisis if the coping mechanisms fail.

These factors combined suggest a severe level of depression that requires professional intervention.

text: hey im year old and ive recently been diagnosed with severe anxiety after ive been struggling with it my entire life i take my med when i need them only which might be bad and i also started therapy n it been helpful anyways ive been struggling with death anxiety for a while every once in a while ill somehow convince myself that it my last day week on earth n that i need to say goodbye to everyone n that this will be the last time im doing this or that etc it so bad to the point where i cant really get out of bed for day bc im scared of death whenever i have plan i keep thinking about all the bad thing that can happen to me so i cancel im scared of flying or driving or anything that can put me in danger tmw im going on a hiking trip n im terrified that it gon na go badly doe anyone have advice on how to deal with this bc i dont want it to stop me from living my life ive been struggling with it ever since i wa a child and i need it to get le intense asap ty

They are canceling plans due to fear, which significantly impacts their ability to engage in normal life activities. This level of impairment is a strong indicator of severe depression.
*   **Anxiety and rumination:** The text shows the individual ruminating over death and possible negative outcomes which may cause an individual to experience an episode of depression.
*   **Long-Standing Issue:** The individual states they have been struggling with these issues since childhood, suggesting a chronic and deeply rooted problem.
*   **Seeking Help:** While the individual is in therapy, the intensity of their anxiety and associated behaviors suggests the current treatment may not be fully effective in managing their symptoms.
*   **Distress and Urgency:** The user expresses a strong desire to alleviate the intensity of their symptoms "ASAP," highlighting their level of distress and the urgency of the situation.

text: although my colleague and bos have been really supportive and nice to me my mind tell me they secretly hate me or just won t express something they don t like of me in the fear that i m new i m socially awkward and many other thing about the job and conversation of the day echo loud in my head in repeat and i just can t think of anything else i scroll through the gram for distraction or read through my astrology happening for the day i don t know how to relax or quiet my mind so many thing bothering me at once
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text exhibits several indicators suggestive of moderate depression:

*   **Negative thoughts and self-doubt:** The individual expresses a belief that their colleagues secretly dislike them, despite evidence to the contrary ("my colleague and boss have been really supportive"). This is a hallmark of negative thought patterns common in depression.
*   **Rumination:** The repetitive looping of thoughts ("conversation of the day echo loud in my head in repeat") is a strong sign of rumination, a key feature of depression and anxiety.
*   **Difficulty concentrating and relaxing:** The inability to quiet the mind and the feeling of being bothered by "so many things at once" indicate impaired concentration and an inability to relax, both common depressive symptoms.
*   **Avoidance/Distraction:** Using Instagram and astrology as distractions suggests an attempt to avoid or cope with the negative feelings and thoughts, further supporting the presence of depressive symptoms.

While the individual acknowledges external support, the intensity of the internal distress and the presence of rumination, concentration difficulties, and avoidance behaviors point towards a moderate level of depression.

The combination of intense negative emotions, cognitive difficulties, and external stressors, suggests severe impact on the individual's well-being and functioning, warranting a rating of 3.

text: levenrambin take it easy and be good to you

text: after a year of unemployment i got positive news yesterday that i got the job it s the perfect position for me and it will be really interesting to start but a usual i can t be happy when i m supposed to be since the congratulation call i have been spiraling a bit heart raising intrusive thought it s always the same thing

The individual acknowledges the "perfect" and "interesting" nature of the opportunity, which should elicit positive emotions. However, they explicitly state an inability to be happy ("i can't be happy when I'm supposed to be"). This anhedonia, or loss of pleasure, is a core symptom of depression. The phrase "it's always the same thing" implies a recurring pattern of negative thoughts and emotional distress, pointing towards a more persistent underlying issue than just a temporary mood dip. Although the individual is functioning well enough to gain employment, the presence of anhedonia, anxiety symptoms, and a history of similar experiences justify a rating of moderate depression.

text: i ve had this discussion with many people irl including my therapist who said that is very specific to you and i wouldn t go around telling people that lmao when i imagine a world where i have to live forever or i have to follow the natural progression of my age until i die naturally it make me feel suffocated panicked and claustrophobic in my own body the fact is that even if we have lost control over every single thing in our life at least at the very minimum we have control over if that life exists or not i take great solace in the fact that my being on this earth everyday is solely by my choice because if i wanted to i could end it at any point of course i don t because i have people i d be hurting here and i have thing i suppose i need to accomplish before i die but i d be a very big liar if i sat here and said that i don t cope by reminding myself that there is a way out there s always a way out
explanation:
**Explanation:**

This excerpt demonstrates several indicators of severe depression:

*   **Suicidal Ideation:** The individual explicitly states that they "could end it at any point" and find "great solace" in knowing they have control over their existence. This points to recurring thoughts about suicide as a coping mechanism.
*   **Sense of Suffocation and Panic:** The description of feeling "suffocated, panicked, and claustrophobic" when contemplating the future suggests a profound sense of dread and hopelessness. This is a key symptom of depressive disorders.
*   **Loss of Control:** While the individual acknowledges having some control over ending their life, the initial statement about "lost control over every single thing" indicates a broader feeling of powerlessness, which is common in depression.
*   **Burden to Others:** The statement "I have people I'd be hurting here" suggests a feeling of being trapped or obligated to stay alive for the sake of others, rather than a genuine desire to live. This can exacerbate feelings of hopelessness and guilt.
*   **Lack of Joy or Motivation:** Acknowledging needing to "accomplish" things before dying indicates a lack of intrinsic motivation or enjoyment in life.
*   **Coping Mechanism:** Using the thought of suicide as a coping mechanism is indicative of severe distress and a reliance on a potentially dangerous thought pattern to manage overwhelming emotions.

The combination of these factors suggests a level of depression that is significantly impacting the individual's well-being and requires professional intervention.

text: now i cant go work in the hospital and enjoy the little fucking thing i do and learn there an all the people i like talking to and i got ta be stuck here for a week with a busted ankle who i dont even know if it will work properly again or not anymore either this year get better or idk but im just tired of every fucking bad this happening to me all the time i thought i wa finally gon na have a job and a boyfriend and turn out the guy doesnt even like me and the manager never called me again at least i wish i had someone that loved me he could come visit and we could talk all night long at this point i really need some cuddle at least

text: a i write this it feel so attention seeking like i am looking for a reason to stay a reason to feel i have all the reason right in front of me my girlfriend my best friend my dog however none of it matter i m drunk and all i want to do is die i m scared i m scared of how that will make my friend family and girlfriend feel how can i put them through that i wish i didn t care i wish i didn t care about their feeling i wish i could just go get a gun or in my car and resume back to the chapter before my birth sometimes surviving an event is the hard part me surviving life is the hard part it feel like i could go in forever forever knowing that it s just chemical in my brain that make me want to blissfully enjoy the enteral slumber that awaits u all medicine scare me what if it change who i am the last time i wa on the medicine i slept for the majority of the day unable to get out of the blissful slumber that carried away my thought and sorrow eventually i ll have the gut if i rid myself of everyone who care
explanation:
**Explanation:**

This text exhibits several critical indicators of extreme depression:

*   **Suicidal Ideation:** The statement "all I want to do is die" and the contemplation of methods ("get a gun or in my car") are explicit expressions of suicidal ideation.
*   **Hopelessness and Worthlessness:** The feeling that "none of it matter" despite having positive relationships indicates a profound sense of hopelessness and the inability to experience joy or connection. The wish to "resume back to the chapter before my birth" reinforces this sense of worthlessness and desire for non-existence.
*   **Intense Emotional Pain:** The writer expresses being "scared" and burdened by the potential impact of their death on loved ones, yet also wishing they "didn't care." This highlights the intensity of their emotional pain and the struggle between wanting to end the pain and feeling guilty about the consequences.
*   **Self-Loathing and Alienation:** The statement "if i rid myself of everyone who care" shows a strong sense of alientation from the people around him. It shows a lack of sense of worth, which is common in individuals struggling with extreme depression.
*   **Previous Treatment Concerns:** The negative experience with medication ("slept for the majority of the day") and the fear of it changing who they are suggest a barrier to seeking or continuing treatment, which exacerbates the situation.
*   **Substance Use:** The mention of being "drunk" suggests potential self-medication, which is often a coping mechanism for underlying depression and can worsen suicidal thoughts.

Given the presence of active suicidal ideation, intense hopelessness, and expressions of wanting to die, this individual is at immediate risk and requires urgent professional intervention.

text: hello i have been dealing with bad anxiety for le than a week now which mean that it might not last for long but the idea of it just going away seems unrealistic and i want to be able to deal with my anxiety in the future if it pursues me for the rest of my life i am year of age and live alone i a couple of close friend and family and before my first panic attack where i thought i wa dying i wa having the best time of my life to be completely honest and it somewhat saddens me that my life took at turn for the worse i have always had bad social anxiety but it ha gotten better though my panic attack and my panicked state since last sunday have me questioning what is happening and if the anxiety stem from something unresolved i acknowledge that this would better be discussed with a therapist but the wait time is long to be clear i have far from lost hope but i would like to hear how you guy on here figured out what might be causing it if you did and lastly everyone should know that anxiety isn t going to be the same forever even if it seems bad it can change for the better just like a person and it is natural even though the body s instinct might be acting out of whack
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text displays several indicators that suggest mild depression:

*   **Sadness and Loss of Enjoyment:** The individual expresses sadness that their life "took a turn for the worse" after experiencing panic attacks. They contrast their current state with a previous period of happiness, indicating a loss of enjoyment in life.
*   **Anxiety and Worry:** While the primary focus is on anxiety, the individual expresses concern about dealing with anxiety in the future. This worry can be a contributing factor to depression.
*   **Questioning and Uncertainty:** The individual is questioning the source of their anxiety and feeling uncertain about what is happening. This sense of uncertainty and lack of control can be linked to depressive feelings.
*   **Hopefulness:** The individual states that they have "far from lost hope" and acknowledges that anxiety can change for the better. This suggests a degree of resilience and an absence of severe hopelessness, which is characteristic of more severe depression.

While the text does not indicate severe symptoms like suicidal ideation, significant changes in appetite or sleep, or profound hopelessness, the presence of sadness, worry, and uncertainty, alongside a recent decline in well-being, warrants a rating of mild depression. The individual's acknowledgment of the need for therapy is also a positive sign, indicating a willingness to seek help.

text: there is nothing more suffocating than the feeling that youre gon na live your life alone it take a lot of strength to not fall apart specially if you already tasted what is like to share your life with someone and knowing that youre gon na be all on your own by the rest of the path i ve spent the last year dreaming abour growing old with someone i consider to be a gift from the heaven only for that dream to be shattered a week ago it s been more than 0 day and im still stuck in despair i cant even sleep in my bed without thinking of him i refuse to find somsomeone else because whats the point in trying to top perfection only to poorly fill the whole your ex left and get your already pulverized heart shattered once more i ve lost my passion to live i ve been carrying anxiety and panic attack for a few year i wa already barely holding it together but this i just the last straw i dont even have a shoulder to cry on anymore what s the point
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text exhibits several indicators of severe depression:

*   **Expressions of profound loneliness and hopelessness:** The individual expresses a deep fear of living life alone and a sense of despair about the future ("I'm still stuck in despair," "I've lost my passion to live," "What's the point?").
*   **Loss and Grief:** The text describes a significant loss (the end of a relationship) that has profoundly impacted the individual. The shattered dream and inability to cope suggest intense grief.
*   **Sleep disturbance:** The individual reports difficulty sleeping due to intrusive thoughts about the lost relationship. This is a common symptom of depression.
*   **Anhedonia:** The individual expresses a loss of interest and pleasure in life ("I've lost my passion to live"). They also express a lack of motivation to pursue new relationships, suggesting a broader lack of interest.
*   **Pre-existing mental health issues:** The individual acknowledges a history of anxiety and panic attacks, which are now exacerbated by the recent loss. This suggests a vulnerability to depression.
*   **Suicidal Ideation:** The statement "what's the point" can be interpreted as passive suicidal ideation. Though, it's not explicit, it indicates a lack of hope and questioning the value of life.
*   **Lack of support system:** "I don't even have a shoulder to cry on anymore" highlights the individual's isolation and lack of social support, which can worsen depressive symptoms.

These factors, combined, indicate that the individual is likely experiencing a severe depressive episode. Professional help should be sought.

text: lately my best friend only long term friend ha just been brushing me off we joke for hour on end and i listen to them vent almost daily but when i brought up that i lost interest in all of my hobby again they go lmao same me a month ago and changed the subject i always put in an effort to be there for them even when i m in a low place and if i m not really able to feel empathy i tell them i refer them to help hotlines they refuse to get actual help i have given them every opportunity to get professional help by making a list of therapist in their area that take their insurance i ve given them every helpline under the sun whenever i have relative advice i give it to them but they always ignore it at one point i just stopped i stopped trying so hard and realized how much they rely on me to do everything for them they asked me a question i usually google it for them and summarize it i told them to google it they got annoyed with me so i cut them off for a few week whenever we started talking again thing were going well but of course a their type doe they eventually fell back into old habit this is strike for me and while i really don t want to lose the positive time we have together they just don t outweigh the negative i m tired i ve put in constant work and effort into being a healthy and stable a i am today and i m honestly not willing to slow down or trip up because of them i m open to any feedback or advice
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text exhibits several indicators of moderate depression:

*   **Loss of Interest in Hobbies:** The individual explicitly states they have "lost interest in all of my hobby again." This is a core symptom of depression, indicating anhedonia (the inability to experience pleasure).
*   **Fatigue and Tiredness:** The individual expresses being "tired" of the situation with their friend. This fatigue can be indicative of depressive symptoms.
*   **Feelings of Frustration and Resentment:** The individual is frustrated with their friend's behavior and feels resentful for the effort they put into the friendship without reciprocation. While not direct symptoms of depression, these feelings can exacerbate and contribute to a depressed state. The statement "they just don't outweigh the negative" suggests a pessimistic outlook on the relationship.
*   **Social Isolation/Withdrawal (Potential):** The individual "cut them off for a few weeks." While presented as a boundary-setting measure, this could also be a sign of social withdrawal, a common symptom of depression.
*   **Feelings of Being Drained:** The individual mentions "slowing down or tripping up because of them," suggesting a feeling of being emotionally drained by the friendship. This sense of being burdened can be linked to depressive feelings.

While the individual doesn't express overt sadness or hopelessness, the combination of anhedonia, fatigue, frustration, and potential social withdrawal points to a moderate level of depression. The user is still able to articulate their feelings and seek feedback, which suggests they are not in a state of extreme depression.

text: torturedlady yea ma naaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaam marwan accent lol
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text "torturedlady yea ma naaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaam marwan accent lol" is brief and lacks significant detail, making a definitive assessment challenging. However, some elements suggest a possible, though mild, depressive state:

*   **"torturedlady"**: This self-descriptor could indicate a sense of suffering or emotional pain.
*   **"naaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaam"**: The elongated "na" could reflect a sense of apathy, disinterest, or emotional exhaustion. The repetition might indicate a lack of motivation or a feeling of being overwhelmed.
*   **"lol"**: While often used casually, in this context, it *could* be a defensive mechanism or an attempt to mask underlying negative feelings. The incongruity of "lol" with the preceding text could suggest an attempt to downplay distress.

**Important Considerations:**

*   **Context is Crucial:** This assessment is based solely on a single, short text. A comprehensive evaluation requires a broader understanding of the individual's history, circumstances, and other communications.
*   **Professional Evaluation Needed:** This is *not* a substitute for a professional mental health assessment. If you are concerned about someone's mental health, encourage them to seek help from a qualified professional.
*   **Limitations of Text-Based Analysis:** Analyzing brief text excerpts has inherent limitations. Subtle nuances in tone, body language, and nonverbal cues are absent, making accurate diagnosis difficult.

text: i forget that i m depressed and not normal because people love to bash me for not caring about most thing other human do like making lot of money and being better than everyone else lmao i made a post earlier about how i ll never do extra work at my job bc it s not worth it knowing from experience and being on that side i know you just get used by company and they never pay you what you deserve so anyway i realized i don t care for most thing other people do lmao and for what why should i care it s not worth caring
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text exhibits several indicators that suggest moderate depression:

*   **Anhedonia (Lack of Interest/Care):** The individual explicitly states "i don’t care for most thing other people do lmao and for what why should i care it’s not worth caring." This demonstrates a significant loss of interest or pleasure in activities and values that are typically considered important by others. This is a core symptom of depression.
*   **Negative Worldview/Cynicism:** The "lmao" doesn't negate the underlying bitterness. The individual's perspective on work and companies is highly cynical ("you just get used by company and they never pay you what you deserve"). This negativity extends to a broader disillusionment with common societal goals like financial success and competition ("being better than everyone else"). This contributes to a pessimistic and hopeless outlook.
*   **Social Alienation/Perceived Criticism:** The statement "people love to bash me for not caring" indicates a sense of social alienation and a perception of being criticized for not conforming to societal norms. This feeling of being misunderstood or rejected can exacerbate depressive symptoms.
*   **Acknowledgement of Depression:** The initial statement, "i forget that i m depressed and not normal," is significant. While they may 'forget', the underlying recognition is there. This self-awareness further reinforces the likelihood of depression.
*   **Emotional Blunting:** The use of "lmao" might be a defense mechanism to mask deeper feelings of sadness or hopelessness. The disconnect between the potentially painful reality and the dismissive tone suggests emotional blunting, a common symptom of depression.

While there's no mention of suicidal ideation or significant functional impairment (which would push the rating higher), the presence of anhedonia, negative worldview, perceived social isolation, and acknowledgement of depression warrants a "Moderate" rating. Further evaluation would be needed to confirm a diagnosis and determine the appropriate course of treatment.

text: i ve tried to do everything right i ve tried so hard it never get better no matter what it s always a circular road and i always end up in the same place i m just so tired
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text excerpt displays several key indicators of severe depression:

*   **Hopelessness and Despair:** The phrases "it never get better no matter what" and "always end up in the same place" strongly suggest a sense of hopelessness and a belief that positive change is impossible. This is a core feature of depression.
*   **Exhaustion and Fatigue:** "I'm just so tired" indicates significant emotional and potentially physical exhaustion. Fatigue is a common and debilitating symptom of depression.
*   **Sense of Failure and Inadequacy:** "I've tried to do everything right...I've tried so hard" suggests a persistent feeling of failure despite significant effort. This can contribute to low self-worth and a negative self-perception.
*   **Circular Thinking:** The description of life as a "circular road" suggests a feeling of being trapped and unable to escape a negative cycle. This is indicative of the rumination and repetitive negative thinking often associated with depression.

The combination of these factors, particularly the intensity of hopelessness and the expressed exhaustion, points to a severe level of depression.

text: for the past two day i ve been having a lot of trouble getting to sleep and i m just worried if this is really something i should be really worried about and no one in my family seems to care that i m having trouble with this so am i just overreacting or is this something o should be concerned about
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text excerpt suggests mild depression based on the following observations:

*   **Sleep Disturbance:** Difficulty sleeping ("trouble getting to sleep") is a common symptom of depression.

*   **Anxiety/Worry:** The individual expresses worry ("worried if this is really something I should be really worried about"), indicating a level of anxiety that can be associated with depression.

*   **Feelings of Isolation/Lack of Support:** The statement that "no one in my family seems to care" suggests feelings of isolation and a lack of perceived social support, which are also linked to depression.

*   **Self-Doubt:** Questioning whether they are "overreacting" indicates a potential lack of self-worth and a tendency to minimize their own experiences, which can be seen in individuals with depression.

The rating is "mild" because the symptoms are described as occurring for "the past two days," suggesting a relatively recent onset and potentially less severe impact than if the symptoms were chronic.

text: i feel like something is broken in me i do not function a well a others getting up going to work doing my online school all of it is exhausting i cut corner everywhere i can but i m also obsessed with making sure the corner i cut look good on paper i don t actually want to do anything ever i could sit at home all day everyday and do nothing i say i have dream but every time i get some pushback i give up i give myself a pat on the back for doing the shit i m supposed to it make me feel broken and wrong how do people learn the discipline to just get up and do what they re supposed to do everyday how do they just keep going what am i missing
explanation:
**Explanation:**

This text exhibits several indicators of severe depression:

*   **Anhedonia and Apathy:** The individual expresses a lack of desire to do anything, stating they could "sit at home all day everyday and do nothing." This points to a significant loss of interest and pleasure in activities.
*   **Fatigue and Exhaustion:** The individual describes daily tasks like work and school as "exhausting" and admits to cutting corners. This persistent fatigue is a hallmark of depression.
*   **Feelings of Inadequacy and Worthlessness:** The statement "i feel like something is broken in me i do not function a well a others" indicates feelings of being flawed and unable to meet expected standards. The frustration over not having discipline and questioning "what am i missing" reinforces this.
*   **Hopelessness and Giving Up:** The admission of giving up easily on dreams after facing "pushback" suggests a sense of hopelessness and a lack of belief in their ability to achieve goals.
*   **Self-Criticism and a Sense of Being "Wrong":** The individual's self-description as "broken and wrong" and their confusion about how others manage daily life demonstrates negative self-perception.

The combination of these factors, particularly the intensity of the negative emotions and the impact on daily functioning, warrants a rating of severe depression. The individual seems to be struggling significantly to cope with basic responsibilities and is experiencing considerable emotional distress.

text: i ve just had enough of everything i don t know what to do anymore or who to talk to i tried to end my life twice through overdose and that didn t work i have episode where i just don t want to be here anymore i get agitated and it doesn t matter what anyone say or doe it doesn t make it any better i fear that i will have an episode of contemplating suicide and i ll just jump off a bridge it s like my mind take over and i don t think of anyone else my last resort is sectioning and i know what it s like i live in uk but i feel like that would be the safest environment for me where i can focus on getting better without having that constant worry of ending my life can anyone provide any advice at all i would appreciate it i just feel like my life is so pointless growing up with a disability being bullied always feeling different to everyone else childhood trauma and now having a constant battle everyday with my mental health i try to get on with life but i always feel like it would be better if i wasn t here
explanation:
**Explanation:**

This text exhibits several critical indicators of extreme depression:

*   **Suicidal Ideation and Attempts:** The individual explicitly states they have attempted suicide twice and continue to experience episodes where they do not want to live. This is a significant marker of severe depression and imminent risk.
*   **Hopelessness and Worthlessness:** The statement "I just feel like my life is so pointless" reflects profound feelings of hopelessness and worthlessness, core symptoms of depression.
*   **Agitation and Irritability:** "I get agitated and it doesn't matter what anyone say or doe it doesn't make it any better" indicates a high level of emotional distress and a lack of responsiveness to support, characteristic of severe depression.
*   **Fear of Self-Harm:** The individual expresses fear of acting on suicidal impulses ("I fear that I will have an episode of contemplating suicide and I'll just jump off a bridge"). This indicates a loss of control and a heightened risk of self-harm.
*   **Seeking External Protection:** The individual identifies sectioning (involuntary hospitalization) as a potential "safest environment," indicating a recognition of their own inability to manage their suicidal urges and a desire for external intervention to prevent self-harm.
*   **History of Trauma and Bullying:** The disclosure of childhood trauma, bullying, and living with a disability provides context for the current mental health crisis and highlights the chronic nature of the individual's struggles.

The combination of active suicidal ideation and attempts, feelings of hopelessness and worthlessness, agitation, fear of self-harm, and a request for help makes it clear that the individual is experiencing extreme depression and requires immediate professional intervention.

text: i used to have worse anxiety but it s been better since i started on adhd medication but every time i now have even small amount of anxiety that don t even amount to an anxiety or panic attack the next day i get really really bad fatigue like i get out of breath from walking across the room and my leg ache despite doing nothing i know tiredness after anxiety is normal but i m getting this after even small amount of anxiety when i didn t have this before even after a day long anxiety attack is this normal or should i book a gp appointment because i end up having to take day off school because of it btw i no longer have anxiety it really is just specific situation such a an anxiety attack about my phobia or even a phone call with a doctor appointment
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text suggests the individual is experiencing several symptoms indicative of moderate depression, even though they state their anxiety has improved. Here's why:

*   **Fatigue and Physical Symptoms:** The individual describes debilitating fatigue, breathlessness, and leg aches, even after minor anxiety triggers. This level of physical manifestation of stress and anxiety, significantly impacting daily functioning (taking days off school), points beyond simple post-anxiety tiredness. Such symptoms can be associated with depression.

*   **Functional Impairment:** The need to take days off school due to the fatigue highlights a clear impact on their ability to function normally. This disruption in daily life is a key indicator of the severity of the mental health condition.

*   **Impact on Daily Life:** The individual expresses a clear disruption in their daily life, indicating the symptoms significantly impact their well-being and ability to function normally. This disruption in daily life is a key indicator of depression.

While the individual states they no longer have anxiety in general, the fact that small anxiety triggers lead to such severe physical and functional consequences suggests an underlying vulnerability. The disproportionate response (extreme fatigue after minor anxiety) is a red flag. This, combined with the disruption in daily life, warrants a moderate depression rating.

text: older people tend to treat young people with anxiety like it s just a new trend and not a serious disorder affecting our daily life constantly trust me i wish i didn t have to demand wfh indefinitely because i ve been almost exclusively working from home for two year and it fucked me up anxiety wise i wish you understood how me not really talking to anyone once i m in the office or opting out of group activity isn t about being a bitch it s because one interaction can mess with my brain for hour and for day if i deemed it wrong in any way it s because i know i ll have to be buzzed on pill the entire time just to have a somewhat decent time i wish i wasn t like this just a much a you wish gen y and or z wouldn t complain about anxiety ruining their life to be lazy and avoid working a hard a you do or whatever you think it mean i wish i didn t experience this incapacitating and invisible disorder every single day of my life
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text exhibits several indicators of severe depression:

*   **Expressions of hopelessness and wishing things were different:** The repeated use of "I wish I didn't have to..." and "I wish I wasn't like this..." reveals a strong desire to escape the current state and a sense of being trapped.

*   **Social withdrawal and avoidance:** The individual describes avoiding social interactions at work due to anxiety triggers, indicating a significant impact on their ability to function in a social environment.

*   **Reliance on medication:** The statement about needing to be "buzzed on pill the entire time just to have a somewhat decent time" suggests a heavy reliance on medication to cope with their anxiety and potentially underlying depression. This dependence signifies a severe level of impairment.

*   **Self-criticism and negative self-perception:** Although directed outward at those who don't understand, there's an underlying current of self-deprecation ("I wish I wasn't like this"). This internalized negativity is common in depression.

*   **Perceived incapacitation:** The individual describes their disorder as "incapacitating and invisible," emphasizing the profound impact it has on their daily life and their perception of it as debilitating.

These factors, combined with the persistent anxiety and resulting impact on work and social life, point to a severe level of depression requiring professional intervention.

This anxiety is not just general worry; it's rooted in past negative experiences and fears of severe side effects, including suicidal ideation. This suggests a deep-seated struggle with their mental health.

*   **Feelings of Helplessness and Being Lost:** The statement "I'm so lost on what to do" underscores feelings of hopelessness and a lack of direction. This is a common symptom of depression.
*   **Conflicted Feelings about Help:** The individual acknowledges needing help ("I really need the help") but is simultaneously terrified of receiving it ("scared of the help"). This ambivalence is a sign of the depth of their distress and fear.

The broken plug might represent a minor disruption to their day that feels disproportionately upsetting. This suggests a reduced capacity to cope with everyday stressors.

It's important to remember that this is a very small snippet of information. This rating is based solely on this single statement and should not be taken as a definitive diagnosis. A more comprehensive assessment would be needed to accurately determine the individual's mental health status.

text: when i wa a teen i would burn myself with match because it made me feel better it ha been many year since i have burned myself today i got swarmed by yellowjackets and stung several time and instantly felt better i m not sure if it s the adrenaline or something else or if i m imagining it thought
explanation:
**Explanation:**

This text excerpt raises significant concerns and points towards severe depression. Here's why:

*   **History of Self-Harm:** The individual has a history of self-harm (burning), which is a major indicator of depression, emotional distress, and potential suicidal ideation.
*   **Current Urge/Feeling:** The statement that being stung by yellowjackets "instantly felt better" is deeply concerning. It suggests that the individual is experiencing a severe lack of emotional regulation and is finding relief in physical pain. This is a dangerous coping mechanism and a hallmark of severe depression and potentially other mental health conditions.
*   **Lack of Insight/Confusion:** While the individual acknowledges they might be imagining the positive feeling, the fact that they even consider it a possibility, rather than immediately recognizing it as an unhealthy and potentially dangerous thought, indicates a significant impairment in their ability to process and understand their emotions.
*  **Passive Suicidal Ideation:** An attraction to pain can be a form of passive suicidal ideation.

text: i ve struggled with anxiety and depression since i wa a teenager i m now so it s been about 0 year of dealing with my silly little brain i first started taking zoloft back in maybe 0 maybe before then but i took the pill for several year last september i started noticing an increase of suicidal thought this can happen with ssri i believe i think the zoloft just stopped working for my brain and body so i stopped cold turkey i didn t have any major issue please don t comment the risk i know what they are and i m doing okay now for a few month i wa fine i could feel my feeling again feel my emotion and it wa kinda nice i felt almost free but after awhile i think all of the zoloft build up left my body sound weird but hear me out and i started feeling a bad a i did when i wa a teen health anxiety er trip panic attack daily so even though i do badly wanted to try to make it without medication i couldn t do it and that is okay for about month i ve been on lexapro and it s been helping the anxiety here s the revelation i had so i have only been on one other ssri in my life so i never realized this but holy fuck i finally understand what people mean when they say that medication almost completely numbs your emotion i can t remember the last time i cried and i usually cry a lot a an emotional person i feel very neutral i don t feel nothing but i don t feel the way i did unmedicated i think there will always be pro and con to medication but damn i finally after a decade understand what this medication doe it help but it also kinda turn you into an emotionless machine weird
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The individual's text reveals a history of anxiety and depression spanning a decade. While they acknowledge the positive effects of Lexapro on their anxiety, they also express concern about emotional numbing. This suggests that while some symptoms are being managed, the individual is experiencing a significant alteration in their emotional experience, which is a common side effect of SSRIs that can contribute to feelings of detachment and, ultimately, a worsening of depressive symptoms in the long run. The history of suicidal thoughts, even if currently managed, indicates a vulnerability. The individual's awareness and articulation of the medication's effects are positive signs, but the overall impact on their emotional well-being warrants a moderate rating.

text: i don t see the meaning of life in general or the purpose of my own life i ve been clinically depressed and in and out of therapy for seven year now which is of my life which make me feel sad i ve reached this point where i don t even have the desire to take an active role in anything that happens to me or in my choice i feel very passive like i m just sort of letting my life lead me instead of leading it i feel dormant like i m just existing and i d barely even call myself alive everyone around me ha relationship thing to look forward to goal to meet etc yet i m only year old and i cant find even one attainable thing that i have the desire to accomplish i know i m not supposed to compare because everyone is different and blah blah blah but i m jealous of others who are driven and motivated i m unhappy and unfulfilled but simultaneously i m burnt out from constantly trying to work on myself get better and look for thing that will help change my mentality i really don t know what i should do next that is if i can bring myself to do anything at all
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text exhibits several indicators of severe depression:

*   **Loss of Meaning and Purpose:** The individual expresses a profound lack of meaning in life, both generally and personally. This is a core symptom of depression.
*   **Anhedonia and Apathy:** They report a lack of desire to take an active role in their life, indicating anhedonia (loss of pleasure) and apathy.
*   **Passivity and Dormancy:** The feelings of passivity and simply "existing" rather than "living" suggest a significant withdrawal from engagement with the world.
*   **Hopelessness:** The inability to find even one attainable goal, coupled with jealousy of others' motivation, indicates a sense of hopelessness about the future.
*   **Burnout from Treatment:** The burnout from trying to improve suggests a long-standing and treatment-resistant depression, which further contributes to the severity.
*   **Suicidal Ideation (Implied):** The final statement, "if I can bring myself to do anything at all," can be interpreted as a passive suicidal thought.

While the individual acknowledges some cognitive distortions ("I'm not supposed to compare"), the overall tone and content strongly suggest a severe level of depression that is significantly impacting their ability to function and experience life.

These factors combined indicate a strong likelihood of severe depressive symptoms, warranting a rating of 3.

text: hey everyone i ve been a long time reader of this sub and i wan na say first of all that i wish you all the best of life truly i m writing this in great sadness my life isn t bad i ve got a good family awesome friend there s nothing obviously wrong about me i study i work i m in my early 0 i ve made the life for myself that i thought i should and needed to have the problem is there s absolutely nothing about my life that make me happy that i can say that truly satisfies and fulfills me about two year ago i decided to made some radical change in my life i lost a ton of weight i started working more on my look my social skill budding up my confidence i got a job that despite being shitty af ha made me somewhat independent financially i feel like i ve come so far like i ve overcome so much yet right now i m writing you this in such a deep sadness i simply feel sad i feel empty i feel alone mostly i feel alone i feel misunderstood i feel like i m out of place i don t belong anywhere that i try to go t i don t belong to anyone and it s been like this every single day for the last year i feel like i m going mad i ve tried all i can and i truly mean this all that i possible could have done to find even the slightest resemblance of happiness but i haven t sometimes it feel like i m finding a way like i m finding some light but then suddenly it all go away i m tired guy it s my biggest shame in life to have to admit this that i somehow find myself in my early 0 saying i don t have any will to live the many year of life that i still have ahead of me and yet this is the truth i m tired and i don t want to continue not this way at least sometimes i wonder why me why did it happen to me
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text exhibits several indicators of severe depression:

*   **Pervasive Sadness and Emptiness:** The individual explicitly states experiencing "deep sadness," feeling "empty," and "alone" consistently for the past year. This persistent negative affect is a hallmark of depression.
*   **Anhedonia:** The inability to find happiness or satisfaction in any aspect of life despite having a seemingly "good" life (family, friends, work) suggests a significant loss of interest and pleasure, a core symptom of depression.
*   **Feelings of Isolation and Alienation:** The individual expresses a profound sense of being "misunderstood," "out of place," and not belonging anywhere or to anyone. This highlights a deep sense of social disconnection and isolation, which is common in depression.
*   **Hopelessness and Suicidal Ideation:** The statement "I don't have any will to live" is a serious indicator of suicidal ideation and a profound sense of hopelessness about the future. This, coupled with the overall tone of exhaustion and despair ("I'm tired and I don't want to continue"), suggests a high level of distress and risk.
*   **Efforts to Improve and Subsequent Relapse:** The individual's efforts to improve their life (weight loss, improving social skills, getting a job) followed by a return to a state of deep sadness and hopelessness indicates the potential for treatment-resistant depression or a particularly severe episode.
*   **Cognitive Symptoms:** The statement "I feel like I'm going mad" can be seen as a cognitive distortion and can be common with individuals experiencing depression.

text: everyday at some point i get this overwhelming urge to kill myself sometimes it when i wake up sometimes it when i fall asleep sometimes it in the middle of the day there is no rhyme or reason to the timing a year ago my best friend who i went to for encouragement and care killed himself and i think he killed himself because he couldnt handle my problem on top of his own i keep cutting myself and while i dont cut that deep it get deeper everytime i do it i feel like im a disappointment to my dad and grandma since i just lay around at the house instead of going to university it just so hard to convince myself to do anything a nothing is fun anymore i used to love playing game but now that is boring and lifeless my dad think i should just push through and maybe i should but it just feel so difficult i feel like im a terrible person who abuse others for emotional gain a i will often make request of others without reciprocating and will get mad and yell at others for doing thing that inconvenience me ive been trying to do better but everytime i seem to improve i come back worse than before i think the world and my family would be better of without me being a parasite i feel like killing myself will ultimately make the world a better place im sorry for the rambling text i probably sound stupid or crazy but i wanted to get my authentic thought out
explanation:
**Explanation:**

This text exhibits multiple, severe indicators of depression, justifying a rating of 4. Here's a breakdown:

*   **Suicidal Ideation:** The individual expresses a recurring and overwhelming urge to kill themselves. This is a critical symptom of severe depression and a significant indicator of risk. They also state that the world and their family would be better off without them, indicating a belief that their death would be beneficial.
*   **Self-Harm:** The individual engages in self-harm (cutting), and the depth of the cuts is increasing, suggesting an escalation of distress and potentially a greater risk of a serious suicide attempt.
*   **Guilt and Self-Blame:** The individual feels responsible for their friend's suicide, indicating intense guilt. They also express feelings of being a disappointment to their family and a burden on others. This negative self-perception is a hallmark of depression.
*   **Anhedonia:** The individual reports a loss of interest and pleasure in activities they once enjoyed (playing games), a core symptom of depression.
*   **Hopelessness:** The statement that "every time I seem to improve I come back worse than before" indicates a sense of hopelessness about the future and a belief that recovery is impossible.
*   **Worthlessness:** The individual describes themselves as a "terrible person who abuse others for emotional gain" and a "parasite," demonstrating profound feelings of worthlessness.
*   **Functional Impairment:** The individual's inability to attend university and their struggle to motivate themselves to do anything highlights significant functional impairment caused by their depression.
*   **Emotional Dysregulation:** The individual admits to yelling at others and getting mad over minor inconveniences, indicating emotional dysregulation that is a common symptom of depression

text: hello i hope you are having a good day i have been suicidal for the last year at least i am 9 male idk if that matter and i never told anyone about it because well i am too shy today i built enough strentgh to be able to open up about my suicidal thought to my mother just to feel absolutely destroyed by her reaction she immedately asked if i am autistic no joke and didnt stop saying that i wa telling her this to threaten her or make her feel guilty i wa very confused when i heard that and she still continued doubting my academic performance even though i told her many time i am still doing well in my study then finally she somehow ended up beating me up out of rage telling me that i am lazy that i dont help at home that i dont pay the bill that i dont get the highest grade making feel me like i am burden to everyone well i guess that must be true right i am worthless so i should disappear soon trust me i want to die really badly but i get slapped by reality and i realize how weak i am when i try killing myself i am sorry for being such a disappointment to everyone i am truly sorry
explanation:
**Explanation:**

This text exhibits several critical indicators of extreme depression:

*   **Suicidal Ideation (Persistent and Intense):** The individual explicitly states they have been suicidal for at least a year and express a strong desire to die ("trust me I want to die really badly"). The longevity and intensity of these thoughts are a major red flag.
*   **Hopelessness and Worthlessness:** The individual expresses profound feelings of worthlessness ("I am worthless so I should disappear soon," "I am sorry for being such a disappointment to everyone"). This negative self-perception is a core symptom of depression.
*   **Triggering Event and Negative Reaction:** The individual describes a deeply invalidating and abusive reaction from their mother after disclosing their suicidal thoughts. This negative interaction has likely exacerbated their existing feelings of hopelessness and worthlessness.
*   **Self-Blame and Apology:** The individual apologizes for being a disappointment, which highlights a tendency to internalize blame and responsibility for negative outcomes.
*   **Helplessness:** The individual notes that they are "weak" because they are not able to even kill themselves.
*   **Age:** The individual is only 9 years old, and thus a high severity rating is warranted due to the vulnerability of the individual.

The combination of these factors, particularly the explicit and persistent suicidal ideation coupled with a traumatic interpersonal experience, suggests a severe and urgent need for professional mental health intervention.

The statement "playing pkr online poker and ha a headache" in isolation provides limited information. However, the key here is the lack of any positive affect or engagement, coupled with a physical complaint (headache). While not definitive, this *could* suggest:

*   **Anhedonia (reduced pleasure):** Someone who is depressed might be engaging in a previously enjoyable activity (online poker) but not deriving much pleasure from it, hence the flat affect in the statement.
*   **Somatic Symptoms:** Headaches are a common physical manifestation of depression.
*   **Withdrawal/Isolation (potential):** Engaging in online poker *could* be a way of isolating oneself, though more context is needed.

Because of these *potential* indicators, a rating of 1 (Mild Depression) is warranted. A higher rating would require more conclusive evidence of depressive symptoms. More information about the individual's usual activities, mood, and other symptoms would be needed for a more accurate assessment.

text: i m about to be living in nyc and have never done anything worth wilde with my life and im sure im doomed to become one of those in the way people who don t do anything in their life which i feared most of my life nothing i seem to attempt to accomplish work out no matter how hard i work or how right i do it i gave so much time to job organization to further my career path only to used a free labor studying only to use up all my forgiveness credit and flunk out i ve been wanting to end it all for a while every time i sleep i see the bk bridge the spot i picked out year ago to end it i feel like i rather be gone than keep living with fact that i m a grown man that s not worth anything hell my mom ha told me that i haven t done anything for her to be proud me and i won t let my partner destroy herself trying to help me i wanted to be an engineer for nasa when i wa younger but here i am today the world shitist it guy that hasn t been able to find a secure job in the past year i ve been desperate for work for a while today i wa given a work assignment from my contract company only to be told i don t exist in the company so i can t work
explanation:
**Explanation:**

This text exhibits several critical indicators of extreme depression, including:

*   **Suicidal Ideation with Planning:** The individual explicitly mentions wanting to "end it all" and details a specific location (Brooklyn Bridge) chosen a year ago, indicating active and prolonged suicidal planning. This is a very serious sign.
*   **Feelings of Worthlessness and Hopelessness:** The individual expresses a profound sense of worthlessness ("grown man that's not worth anything"), hopelessness ("doomed," "nothing I seem to attempt to accomplish work out"), and failure ("haven't done anything for her to be proud").
*   **Loss of Interest and Motivation:** The text indicates a loss of interest in previously held aspirations (engineer for NASA) and a feeling of being stuck in a dead-end situation ("world shittiest it guy").
*   **Self-Blame and Negative Self-Perception:** The individual internalizes blame for their perceived failures and expresses a highly negative view of themselves.
*   **Intense Emotional Pain:** The statement about not wanting their partner to "destroy herself trying to help me" suggests significant emotional pain and a desire to protect others from the burden of their suffering.
*   **Recent Triggering Event:** The work assignment issue and feeling "I don't exist" seems to be a recent event that has worsened their feelings.

These factors, especially the active suicidal ideation and specific planning, warrant immediate concern and indicate a state of extreme depression requiring urgent professional intervention.

text: literally spitting blood
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The phrase "literally spitting blood" is alarming and suggests a significant level of distress. While it could be interpreted literally as a medical emergency, without further context, in a mental health assessment, it is more likely a hyperbolic expression of intense emotional pain and suffering. This level of emotional intensity, using a violent and visceral image, points towards:

*   **Intense emotional pain:** "Spitting blood" suggests a feeling of being overwhelmed and damaged.
*   **Possible suicidal ideation (passive):** The phrase implies a level of self-destruction, even if not explicitly stated.
*   **Hopelessness:** The extreme nature of the statement can be associated with feelings of despair and a lack of belief that things can improve.

Therefore, based solely on this statement, a rating of 3 (Severe Depression) is warranted due to the intensity of the imagery and the implied emotional distress. A thorough assessment would be needed to confirm the diagnosis and explore the underlying causes.

text: in high school i wa quiet mind my business didn t talk to many people i noticed that certain people just didn t like me one time a teacher moved a girl to sit next to me and she made this weird face like annoyed and when she sat next to me she wa slightly turned ti the direction i wasn t in and not facing straight another occasion i wa sitting in a table with other people and none of them would bother to talk to me even when i tried to make a convo or ask a question and one of them actually cut hair now and my brother and dad cut their hair with her and they re always saying she talk a lot etc she s friendly today i went to that place to cut my hair and she wa completely quiet just asked me what hair type i wanted and the price of the cut i didn t want to start a convo cause i knew that back then she wouldn t even want to talk i just feel like i have something that just make people dislike me for no reason

*   **Negative Self-Perception:** The statement "I just feel like I have something that just makes people dislike me for no reason" reveals a negative self-perception and a belief that they are inherently unlikeable. This can be linked to low self-esteem, a symptom of depression.
*   **Rumination on Past Experiences:** The individual is dwelling on past experiences of social rejection, which suggests a tendency to ruminate on negative events. This is common in depression and can contribute to feelings of sadness and hopelessness.
*   **Emotional Numbness/Avoidance:** The individual's decision not to engage in conversation ("I didn't want to start a convo cause I knew that back then she wouldn't even want to talk") may indicate a fear of further rejection and a withdrawal from social interaction, which are signs of depression. The quietness of the interaction could also be signs of emotional numbness.

text: i would like to know if anyone ha experienced the same thing a me or at least close to it and how ha he coped or even solved it to get you up to speed last summer i had to go meet my long distance girlfriend and thats when it all started a week prior to her coming to see me i wa gagging when eating and generally feeling sick because i wa afraid worried of meeting her which wa not normal of me but it happend during that period i did not think any of it a i thought it would stop happening after i meet her and leave again but it stayed i have it when i am going to school and when i eat from the time i leave my house and reach the school i gag all the way but when i step my foot there it stop when i eat after i finish i will start gagging and fight with my self not to puke january of this year came and i had almost removed it from my daily life maybe because i got used to the thing i wa doing so they did not give me anxiety but when i have to do something out of the ordinary it get me for example when i went to a car meet week ago the day where the car meet wa hosted i wa feeling a bit sick and right before i left my house i puked out of anxiety i dont know how to remove it completely from my life all i want it to just live freely with out having to worry if my gagging anxiety will kick in if someone can help me or give me a tip i would gladly appreciate it
explanation:
**Explanation:**

The text exhibits several indicators that suggest a moderate level of depression, intertwined with anxiety:

*   **Anxiety and Physical Symptoms:** The individual describes experiencing significant anxiety manifested through physical symptoms like gagging and vomiting, particularly in anticipation of specific events (meeting girlfriend, attending car meet). This suggests a potential anxiety disorder, but the persistent nature and impact on daily life contribute to a depressive picture.
*   **Impact on Daily Life:** The anxiety and physical symptoms are disrupting daily routines. The individual gags on the way to school and after eating, indicating a significant impact on their ability to function normally and enjoy everyday activities.
*   **Avoidance and Worry:** The individual worries about the anxiety and gagging "kicking in," leading to a state of constant vigilance and fear. This anticipatory anxiety further restricts their life and contributes to a feeling of helplessness. The individual also mentioned they had almost removed it from their daily life, but when they have to do something out of the ordinary it gets to them.
*   **Seeking Help:** The individual is actively seeking help and tips, indicating a desire to improve their situation and a recognition that their current coping mechanisms are insufficient. This acknowledgment of a problem and motivation for change are significant.

While the text doesn't explicitly mention sadness, hopelessness, or loss of interest, the anxiety, physical symptoms, disruption of daily life, and worry warrant a rating of moderate depression. The symptoms are more than just occasional stress and are impacting the individual's ability to function and experience life freely.

text: december of 0 i wa hurting pretty bad anxiety through the roof anger issue depression then more anxiety here month later i m not at all the same person i m not getting the panic wave going to a store or meeting new people i m not fearful of conversation a much lol and i ve even been planning a trip or two with the family since jan st i ve lost pound in a healthy way 0lbs to 9 i ve changed my diet been excersizing been talking to other people who are trying to lose weight get healthier it s changed everything i m fitting into jean i put in storage year ago i have work shirt that i ve literally never fit in that are my favorite to wear now i m due for a check up with my doc and i m going to talk about reducing my anti anxiety med and my blood pressure med and that feel amazing and sure i ve had a set back or two some day i eat better than others but that s ok ive had cake kolaches and starbucks at time i didnt have to cut out all the food i craved just control my portion which happens a little at a time and make some substitution that i can t even tell anymore i know this shoe won t fit everyone s foot but making these change ha changed everything for me get out get healthier be more active be engaged most importantly trying is more than enough just being able to look back to when i wasn t even trying and i thought that wa just how life wa going to be is a huge mood booster maybe it d work for you too p i am in a paid program i signed up for i don t want to solicit anything so i m not sharing the info of that program in this post also in some therapy but personally the weight loss ha made more of a difference to me

While the individual acknowledges occasional setbacks ("some day i eat better than others"), the overall tone is optimistic and forward-looking. The fact that they are considering reducing their anxiety and blood pressure medication is another sign of improvement.

The presence of past struggles with anxiety, anger, and depression, coupled with the mention of ongoing therapy, suggests a vulnerability to mood-related issues. However, the current positive outlook and active efforts to maintain well-being indicate that the individual is experiencing only mild symptoms, if any, at the present time.
